docs.lead_paragraph: As Hillary Rodham Clinton begins her official United States Senate campaign, her husband has presented Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani with two disagreeable alternatives: Criticize billions of dollars in Clinton education and anticrime initiatives that would help New York City, or praise the husband of his political enemy. In his State of the Union speech last month and in his 2001 budget to be released next week, President Clinton is offering up a cornucopia of popular programs aimed at bolstering Democrats, but chiefly Al Gore and the first lady. Some are already bringing in millions of dollars for new teachers and after-school programs in Harlem and the Hunts Point section of the Bronx. Others, like gun control, are issues on which Mr. Giuliani, Mrs. Clinton's opponent, has aligned himself with the president in the past.

headline.main: Political Memo; President's Budget Plans Put Mayor on Spot

docs.abstract: Elisabeth Bumiller, in Political Memo column, holds that Pres Clinton has presented Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani with two disagreeable alternatives as Hillary Rodham Clinton begins her official US Senate campaign: criticize billions of dollars in Clinton education and anticrime initiatives that would help New York City, or praise husband of his political enemy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Every morning, Stan Pestotnik, a pharmacist, studies reports on several dozen patients at LDS Hospital, one of the nation's most technologically advanced hospitals. He zeros in on two or three who have been flagged by a computer as dangerously close to being harmed by medications they are taking. Seriously ill patients often take 10 or 20 drugs at doses so high that vital organs can be destroyed. As soon as tests indicate deterioration, the computer issues an alert and suggests changes. Mr. Pestotnik visits the patients and consults with nurses, then telephones their doctors, typically recommending stopping a drug or reducing the dosage.

headline.main: Corrective Medicine; New Technology Helps Health Care Avoid Mistakes

docs.abstract: Hospitals nationwide, faced with growing concern about sometimes fatal medical errors, are increasingly turning to computers for timely safety check; LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City is in vanguard, one of handful of medical centers that have spent several years developing electronic systems that make treatments safer and more effective; but big New York medical centers are also in thick of trend; at least dozen technology companies, like Cerner and McKesson HBOC, are selling off-the-shelf versions of systems; many have been developed at teaching hospitals; they include Internet links to doctor's laptop, advice-giving software equipped with artificial intelligence, wireless devices that transmit medical orders and bar-code systems to avoid drug errors; computer systems developed by Cerner, Eclipsys Corp and Shared Medical Systems Corp discussed; graphs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Every morning, Stan Pestotnik, a pharmacist, studies reports on several dozen patients at LDS Hospital, one of the nation's most technologically advanced hospitals. He zeros in on two or three who have been flagged by a computer as dangerously close...

docs.lead_paragraph: An arbitrator's ruling yesterday would require the state to offer health benefits to the same-sex partners of state employees. The ruling would apply to gay couples and not affect employees in unmarried, opposite-sex living arrangements. It will take effect unless a two-thirds majority of one house of the Legislature says there is not enough money to pay the benefit.

headline.main: Arbitrator Seeks Benefits For Same-Sex Partners

docs.abstract: Arbitrator's ruling will require Connecticut to offer health benefits to same-sex partners of state employees; ruling will apply to gay couples and not affect employees in unmarried, opposite-sex living arrangements (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the nation's biggest health insurer, said yesterday that it was restating earnings for seven quarters of 1998 and 1999 at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission. But the commission evidently did not object to accounting arrangements that softened the impact on earnings after Aetna bought Prudential Healthcare last summer.

headline.main: At the S.E.C.'s Request, Aetna Is Restating Earnings for 7 Quarters

docs.abstract: Aetna, nation's biggest health insurer, says it is restating earnings for seven quarters of 1998 and 1999 at request of Securities and Exchange Commission; commission does not object to accounting arrangements that softened impact on earnings after Aetna bought Prudential Healthcare last summer; analysts say announcement lifts one of several clouds that had depressed Aetna stock, which has declined almost 40 percent in last 12 months; SEC asked company to change its accounting for 1997 sale of its mental health managed care unit to Magellan Health Services; change will reduce after-tax earnings this year by $39 million, about 4 percent of projected earnings per share (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to protect the slim majority that they hold in the State Senate, Republican leaders have been steering their house toward a more moderate course on several important issues, from health care and abortion rights to lobbying reform. The maneuvering has surprised and angered many conservatives within the Republican Party and, to a lesser degree, placed Senate leaders in direct conflict with Gov. George E. Pataki, their most important ally in the State Capitol.

headline.main: Seeking to Keep Tight Control of Senate, G.O.P. Leaders Shift to Center

docs.lead_paragraph: Asthma and infections like pneumonia and bronchitis accounted for more than half the hospitalizations of children from 1 to 4 years old in a major study of children's health in the United States. The research, the most comprehensive in a decade, also found that the conditions were responsible for nearly a third of hospital stays for 5- to 9-year-olds. Among 15- to 17-year-olds, 3 out of 10 hospitalizations were for pregnancy or childbirth. And for younger adolescents, depression and other mental disorders were the main diagnoses, accounting for more than 9 percent of hospital stays for 10- to 14-year-olds, compared with less than 2 percent for adults.

headline.main: Why Children End Up in the Hospital

docs.lead_paragraph: Shortly after a speech in which he had, by implication, questioned George W. Bush's readiness to be commander in chief and linked him to Clintonesque fund-raising techniques, Senator John McCain was asked if he was violating his promise not to indulge in negative campaigning. ''I think I'm close,'' Mr. McCain said with a laugh. As usual, he was being more candid -- and wittier -- than the other leading candidates about a game that all of them are playing to some degree. On the Republican side, for example, Mr. Bush responds to the hint that he will need ''on the job training'' by depicting Senator McCain as a crypto-Democrat who is ''mimicking'' Al Gore's timid tax cuts. In the Democratic campaign, the exchanges between Vice President Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley are blunter and more personal. But the plain fact is that all four are ready to go negative when it serves their interests, and each man is capable of histrionic displays of virtue when he thinks he can accuse an opponent of taking the low road. The entire show provides an opportunity to reflect on exactly what constitutes negative campaigning, what conditions bring it to the surface and what value it can bring to a campaign.
docs.abstract: Editorial examines negative campaigning by Democrats and Republicans during campaigning for New Hampshire primary; says candidates have all been ready to go negative when it serves their interests, and are similarly capable of 'histrionic displays' of virtue (M)
